questions.question_text: Carbon forms four bonds because it has:
questions.explanation: Carbon has four valence electrons and needs four more to complete its octet. It forms four covalent bonds by sharing electrons.

questions.question_text: An sp³ hybridized carbon has what geometry?
questions.explanation: sp³ hybridization creates four equivalent hybrid orbitals arranged tetrahedrally with 109.5° bond angles. Found in alkanes and saturated carbons.

questions.question_text: The bond angle in an sp² hybridized carbon is approximately:
questions.explanation: sp² hybridization results in trigonal planar geometry with 120° bond angles. Found in alkenes and carbonyls. One p orbital remains unhybridized for π bonding.

options: B. One sigma and two pi bonds
C. Two sigma and one pi bond
questions.explanation: A triple bond contains one sigma bond (head-on overlap) and two pi bonds (side-by-side p orbital overlap). Found in alkynes.

options: A. Down a group and left across a period
B. Up a group and right across a period
C. Down a group and right across a period
D. Up a group and left across a period
questions.explanation: Electronegativity increases going up a group (smaller atoms, electrons closer to nucleus) and right across a period (more protons, stronger nuclear pull).

questions.question_text: A polar covalent bond results when:
questions.explanation: Polar covalent bonds form when atoms with different electronegativities share electrons unequally. The more electronegative atom has a partial negative charge.
Resonance structures have the same arrangement of atoms but different distributions of electrons (particularly pi electrons and lone pairs).

options: A. Valence electrons + bonds + lone pair electrons
B. Valence electrons - bonds - lone pair electrons
C. Valence electrons - bonds - (lone pair electrons ÷ 2)
D. Valence electrons - bonds + lone pair electrons
questions.explanation: Formal charge = valence electrons - number of bonds - nonbonding electrons. This helps determine the best Lewis structure.

options: A. Same connectivity but different spatial arrangement
C. Same molecular formula and same structure
questions.explanation: Constitutional isomers have the same molecular formula but different connectivity—atoms bonded to different partners. Example: butane and isobutane.

questions.question_text: The C-H bond in methane is best described as:
questions.explanation: C-H bonds are slightly polar (C is slightly more electronegative than H), but the difference is small (~0.4). Often treated as essentially nonpolar in practice.

options: A. Side-by-side overlap of p orbitals
C. Overlap of d orbitals only
questions.explanation: Sigma bonds form from head-on (end-to-end) overlap of orbitals along the internuclear axis. They're stronger than pi bonds and allow free rotation.

options: C. Formed by side-by-side overlap of p orbitals
questions.explanation: Pi bonds form from side-by-side (lateral) overlap of parallel p orbitals. They're weaker than sigma bonds, restrict rotation, and are found in double and triple bonds.

questions.question_text: An sp hybridized carbon is found in:
questions.explanation: sp hybridization occurs in alkynes (triple bonds) and nitriles. It creates two hybrid orbitals in a linear geometry (180°) with two unhybridized p orbitals for pi bonds.
Carbocation stability: tertiary > secondary > primary > methyl. More alkyl groups stabilize the positive charge through hyperconjugation and inductive effects.

options: A. Electron movement through pi bonds
B. Electron movement through sigma bonds
questions.explanation: The inductive effect is electron density shift through sigma bonds due to electronegativity differences. It decreases with distance.

questions.question_text: Which functional group contains a carbonyl (C=O)?
questions.explanation: Ketones contain a carbonyl group (C=O) with two carbon substituents. Aldehydes, carboxylic acids, and esters also contain carbonyls.

options: B. Only C-C single bonds and C-H bonds
questions.explanation: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons containing only carbon-carbon single bonds and carbon-hydrogen bonds. General formula: CnH2n+2.

questions.question_text: The molecular orbital that results from constructive overlap is called:
questions.explanation: Constructive overlap (in-phase combination) creates a bonding molecular orbital with electron density between nuclei, lower in energy than the original atomic orbitals.

questions.question_text: The acidity of carboxylic acids compared to alcohols is due to:
options: B. Resonance stabilization of the conjugate base
questions.explanation: Carboxylic acids are more acidic because their conjugate base (carboxylate) is resonance-stabilized—the negative charge is delocalized over two oxygen atoms.

options: A. Free rotation around double bonds
B. Restricted rotation around double bonds
questions.explanation: The pi bond in a double bond prevents rotation, so groups can be on the same side (cis) or opposite sides (trans) of the double bond.
Conformational isomers (conformers) interconvert through rotation around single bonds. Examples: staggered vs. eclipsed ethane, chair vs. boat cyclohexane.

questions.question_text: London dispersion forces are strongest for molecules that are:
options: B. Large with high surface area
questions.explanation: London dispersion forces increase with molecular size and surface area (more electrons, more polarizable). Long chains have stronger LDFs than compact spheres of same MW.

options: B. H bonded to F, O, or N and a lone pair acceptor
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonds form when H is bonded to highly electronegative F, O, or N, and interacts with a lone pair on another F, O, or N.

questions.question_text: The hybridization of carbon in a carbonyl group is:
questions.explanation: The carbonyl carbon is sp² hybridized with trigonal planar geometry. One p orbital forms the pi bond with oxygen.

questions.question_text: Which species is the most stable carbanion?
questions.explanation: Carbanion stability is opposite to carbocations: methyl > primary > secondary > tertiary. Alkyl groups are electron-donating and destabilize negative charge.

options: D. Has no effect on reactivity
questions.explanation: EWGs withdraw electron density, stabilizing nearby negative charges (anions) and destabilizing positive charges. Examples: -NO2, -CN, -CF3.

questions.question_text: Aldehydes differ from ketones in that aldehydes have:
options: B. At least one hydrogen on the carbonyl carbon
C. Two alkyl groups on the carbonyl
questions.explanation: Aldehydes have at least one H attached to the carbonyl carbon (at the end of a chain). Ketones have two carbon groups (alkyl or aryl) attached to the carbonyl.
Ethers have an oxygen atom bonded to two carbon groups (R-O-R'). They're relatively unreactive and often used as solvents.

questions.question_text: The formal charge on nitrogen in ammonium ion (NH4+) is:
questions.explanation: FC = valence e⁻ - bonds - lone pairs = 5 - 4 - 0 = +1. Nitrogen has 5 valence electrons, forms 4 bonds, and has no lone pairs in NH4+.

questions.question_text: A primary carbon is bonded to:
questions.explanation: Primary carbon: bonded to 1 other carbon. Secondary: 2 carbons. Tertiary: 3 carbons. Quaternary: 4 carbons.

options: A. Energy released when a bond forms
B. Energy required to break a bond homolytically
C. Energy required to break a bond heterolytically
questions.explanation: Bond dissociation energy (BDE) is the energy required to homolytically break a bond, producing two radicals. Higher BDE means stronger bond.
Bond polarity depends on electronegativity difference. C-O is most polar because O is most electronegative. Electronegativity: O > N > C ≈ H.

options: B. Movement of sigma bond electrons
C. Movement of pi electrons and lone pairs
questions.explanation: Resonance involves delocalization of pi electrons and lone pairs—they can be shown in different positions in different resonance structures. Sigma bonds and atoms stay fixed.

questions.question_text: Amines are classified as primary, secondary, or tertiary based on:
options: A. The carbon to which they're attached
B. Number of carbons attached to nitrogen
C. Number of hydrogens on nitrogen
questions.explanation: Amine classification is based on number of C atoms bonded to N: primary (1C), secondary (2C), tertiary (3C). This differs from carbon classification.

options: B. Molecules with symmetric geometry that cancel individual dipoles
questions.explanation: Even molecules with polar bonds can have zero net dipole if the geometry is symmetric and individual bond dipoles cancel (e.g., CO2, CCl4).

questions.question_text: The HOMO-LUMO gap is important for:
questions.explanation: The HOMO-LUMO gap (highest occupied-lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) determines light absorption (color) and affects chemical reactivity.

options: A. Part of the double bond
B. Adjacent to a double bond
C. Part of an aromatic ring
D. At the end of a chain
questions.explanation: Allylic position is the carbon adjacent to a C=C double bond. Allylic carbocations and radicals are stabilized by resonance with the pi system.

options: B. Planar, cyclic, fully conjugated, with 4n+2 pi electrons
questions.explanation: Hückel's rule: aromatic compounds are cyclic, planar, fully conjugated, and have 4n+2 pi electrons. This gives exceptional stability.

questions.question_text: Benzene has how many pi electrons?
questions.explanation: Benzene has 6 pi electrons (4n+2 where n=1). Each of the 6 carbon atoms contributes one electron from its unhybridized p orbital.

options: A. Adjacent to a double bond
B. Part of the C=C double bond
C. Part of an aromatic ring
questions.explanation: Vinylic position refers to carbons that are part of the C=C double bond (sp² hybridized). Allylic is adjacent to the double bond.

questions.question_text: The C-C bond length in ethane compared to ethene is:
questions.explanation: Single bonds are longer than double bonds. Ethane C-C: ~1.54 Å. Ethene C=C: ~1.34 Å. Triple bonds are even shorter (~1.20 Å).

options: B. Delocalizing pi electrons over multiple atoms
questions.explanation: Conjugation allows pi electrons to delocalize over several atoms, lowering energy and increasing stability. Requires alternating single and double bonds.

questions.question_text: A carboxylic acid has the structure:
questions.explanation: Carboxylic acids contain a carboxyl group (-COOH): a carbonyl with a hydroxyl attached to the same carbon. They're acidic due to resonance stabilization of the conjugate base.
Esters form by condensation of a carboxylic acid and an alcohol, with loss of water. General structure: R-COO-R'.

options: A. A carbonyl bonded to nitrogen
questions.explanation: Amides have a carbonyl carbon bonded to a nitrogen atom. They're less reactive than other carbonyl compounds due to resonance with the nitrogen lone pair.

questions.question_text: The pKa of a stronger acid is:
options: C. The same for all acids
D. Not related to acid strength
questions.explanation: pKa = -log Ka. Stronger acids have larger Ka values and therefore lower pKa values. HCl (strong acid) has pKa ≈ -7; acetic acid (weak) has pKa ≈ 4.75.

options: D. Have no effect on stability
questions.explanation: EDGs donate electron density, stabilizing positive charges (carbocations) and destabilizing negative charges (carbanions). Examples: -OH, -NH2, -alkyl.

questions.question_text: The most electronegative element in organic chemistry is typically:
questions.explanation: Among common elements in organic molecules, oxygen (3.44) > nitrogen (3.04) > carbon (2.55) > hydrogen (2.20) in electronegativity.
Nitriles (R-C≡N) contain a carbon-nitrogen triple bond. The carbon is sp hybridized with linear geometry.
Antibonding orbitals are designated with an asterisk (*): σ* and π*. They result from destructive overlap and have a node between nuclei.
